statement.p: Instructions call for producing a solution of dextrose that contains 25 g of the provided dry solute with 50 mL of sterile water. What is the
dilution ratio: Preview Question 1 Part 1 of 3
dilution factor: Preview Question 1 Part 2 of 3
percent concentration: Preview Question 1 Part 3 of 3

solution.p: We use the definitions for solutions of dry ingredients in a solution.
The dilution ratio is defined to be grams of solute per mL of diluent added. We have 25 g of solute with 50 mL of diluent added, so the ratio is 25/50.

The dilution factor is defined to be grams of solute per mL of solution resulting. We have 25 g of solute in 50 mL of diluent, so the ratio is 25/50. Sometimes it is written as simply 50. Note, this matches dilution ratio because the solute adds almost no volume to the solution (too small to measure).

The percent concentration is defined to be grams of solute per mL of solution resulting written as a percent. We have 25 g of solute in 50 mL of diluent, so the percent is \displaystyle\frac{{25}}{{50}}\cdot{100}={50}\%.
